   Assessment and Plan
   50 yo M  HIV, h/o PCP pneumonia, now ARDS [**2-20**] [**Month/Day (2) **] c/b DIC
     #. Respiratory Status: [**Month/Day (2) **] Positive.  PCP negative
   [**Name Initial (PRE) **] Respiratory status continued to improve over the past 24 hours, with
   decreasing Fi02 requirement and resolution of hypercarbia and acidosis
   at same pressure settings, however this am appeared to acutely become
   hypoxic with decreasing TV.  Most likely positional atelectasis vs
   mucous plugging/airway obstruction (RT appreciated partial occlusive ?
   mucous in ETT)
   -Increase Fi02, attempt to suction ETT, pt unlikely to tolerate bronch
   or ETT switch. Will manage conservitavely for now. No weaning down of
   driving pressures/PEEP for now.
   - will cont to wean vent settings as tolerated; con
t with
   pentobarbital for now before switching to midaz/fentanyl to prevent
   dysynchrony and try to wean as much as possible
   - goal PaO2 >65; currently patient meeting goal.
   - Appreciate ID input, pt currently on levaquin for [**Name Initial (PRE) 476**], per
   their recs have d/c
d vancomycin, cefepime, azithromycin.
   - Had mini BAL yesterday, gram stain unremarkable, continue to follow
   up results.
   - cont acetaminophen for fever- still continues to spike despite
   antibiotics
   - cont nebs
   - resend sputum given temperature
   #Elevated pancreatic enzymes. Markedly elevated from prior (normal
   [**4-25**]).  Unclear precipitant for pancreatitis. Has not been on propofol
   for some time.  Given pt has HIV, is at risk for extrapulmonary
   manifestations of legionellosis, ? unknown if this has been known to
   affect pancreas.
   -literature search for current meds, risk for pancreatitis (xigris,
   pentobarbital)
   -Monitor hemodynamics, aggressive fluid rescusitation if needed for
   third spacing, caution for now given respiratory status.
   -Continue trophic feeds via NGT, do not advance for now.
   -Continue to monitor Ca, HCT, hemodynamics.
   -Necrotizing pancreatitis may be etiology for fevers, pt currently not
   stable enough for CT, but should consider when possible. Discuss with
   ID need to start meropenem.
   -continue to trenf enzymes
   2. ?DIC.  DIC frequently described sequelae of legionellosis.  Pt has
   had abnormalities in his DIC panel as well as a confusing picture of
   symmetric distal extremity ischemia,  more consistent in appearance
   with vasoocclusion related to pressors (which pt has not received)
   rather than DIC/microangiopathic thrombosis.  The magnitide of the
   digital ischemia is out of proportion to the degree of abnormality of
   DIC. Also on ddx is croglobulinema, pt has HIV which has not been
   associated with increased incidence of DIC, unlike HCV. No known
   history of HCV, last serology here [**2101**].
   - cont to monitor labs; fibrinogen improved this AM
   - cont activated protein C, will have completed today at 1700
   - transfusion parameters- if Hct<25, cryo for fibrinogen <100, plts if
   less than 35 though may worsen coagulopathy.
   - No need for anticoagulation at this time.  Had IVC filter placed
   yesterday for DVT
   - continue to monitor exam, call vascular surgery if pt develops
   evidence for wet gangrene that could be fuelling sepsis.
   -f/u cryoglobulins (send yesterday, a send out, should take ~10 days)
   -check HCV serology
   3. Hyperthermia. Pt
s fever curve as decreased slightly, however tmax
   still >103F.
   - likely source is infectious- [**Year (4 digits) 476**] known to cause prolonged high
   fevers and course is known to be more severe in HIV positive patients
   however fevers are of impressive duration and severity.  Warrants probe
   for alternative sources of which he has many:
   - ID consulted, appreciate their input. Rec imaging sinuses and torso
   with CT (look for cavitary lesions in lungs, sinuses to look for
   extrapulmonary [**Year (4 digits) 476**], abd to look for other abscess, necrotizing
   pancreatitis).
   - continue levaquin for PNA
   -  found to have DVT in R popliteal/superficial femoral.  s/p IVC
   filter
   - ATC tylenol
   - cooling blankets PRN
   4. Acute Kidney Injury- urine sediment with casts c/w ATN, low SG c/w
   poor concentrating ability.  Cr down slightly to 3.5, persistently
   uremic. No hyperkalemia, still making urine, no indication for dialysis
   at present.
   - cont to monitor.
   - will renally dose medications.
   - started calcium carbonate for calcium/phos product >50 with good
   response.
   5. Hypernatremia- likely in the setting of diuresis and had been NPO
   - Free h20 deficit ~5L, did not respond to free h20 flushes, may not be
   absorbing adequately from GI tract.  Will give D5W, recheck lytes in pm
   and adjust free water repletion accordingly.
   - stopped lasix gtt
   6. HIV- hold HAART for now; low VL and high CD4

   50 yo M  HIV, h/o PCP pneumonia, now ARDS [**2-20**] [**Month/Day (2) **] c/b DIC
     #. Respiratory Status: [**Month/Day (2) **] Positive.  PCP negative
   [**Name Initial (PRE) **] Respiratory status continued to improve over the past 24 hours, with
   decreasing Fi02 requirement and resolution of hypercarbia and acidosis
   at same pressure settings, however this am appeared to acutely become
   hypoxic with decreasing TV.  Most likely positional atelectasis vs
   mucous plugging/airway obstruction (RT appreciated partial occlusive ?
   mucous in ETT)
   -Increase Fi02, attempt to suction ETT, pt unlikely to tolerate bronch
   or ETT switch. Will manage conservitavely for now. No weaning down of
   driving pressures/PEEP for now.
   - will cont to wean vent settings as tolerated; con
t with
   pentobarbital for now before switching to midaz/fentanyl to prevent
   dysynchrony and try to wean as much as possible
   - goal PaO2 >65; currently patient meeting goal.
   - Appreciate ID input, pt currently on levaquin for [**Name Initial (PRE) 476**], per
   their recs have d/c
d vancomycin, cefepime, azithromycin.
   - Had mini BAL yesterday, gram stain unremarkable, continue to follow
   up results.
   - cont acetaminophen for fever- still continues to spike despite
   antibiotics
   - cont nebs
   - resend sputum given temperature
   #Elevated pancreatic enzymes. Markedly elevated from prior (normal
   [**4-25**]).  Unclear precipitant for pancreatitis. Has not been on propofol
   for some time.  Given pt has HIV, is at risk for extrapulmonary
   manifestations of legionellosis, ? unknown if this has been known to
   affect pancreas.
   -literature search for current meds, risk for pancreatitis (xigris,
   pentobarbital)
   -Monitor hemodynamics, aggressive fluid rescusitation if needed for
   third spacing, caution for now given respiratory status.
   -Continue trophic feeds via NGT, do not advance for now.
   -Continue to monitor Ca, HCT, hemodynamics.
   -Necrotizing pancreatitis may be etiology for fevers, pt currently not
   stable enough for CT, but should consider when possible. Discuss with
   ID need to start meropenem.
   -continue to trenf enzymes
   2. ?DIC.  DIC frequently described sequelae of legionellosis.  Pt has
   had abnormalities in his DIC panel as well as a confusing picture of
   symmetric distal extremity ischemia,  more consistent in appearance
   with vasoocclusion related to pressors (which pt has not received)
   rather than DIC/microangiopathic thrombosis.  The magnitide of the
   digital ischemia is out of proportion to the degree of abnormality of
   DIC. Also on ddx is croglobulinema, pt has HIV which has not been
   associated with increased incidence of DIC, unlike HCV. No known
   history of HCV, last serology here [**2101**].
   - cont to monitor labs; fibrinogen improved this AM
   - cont activated protein C, will have completed today at 1700
   - transfusion parameters- if Hct<25, cryo for fibrinogen <100, plts if
   less than 35 though may worsen coagulopathy.
   - No need for anticoagulation at this time.  Had IVC filter placed
   yesterday for DVT
   - continue to monitor exam, call vascular surgery if pt develops
   evidence for wet gangrene that could be fuelling sepsis.
   -f/u cryoglobulins (send yesterday, a send out, should take ~10 days)
   -check HCV serology
   3. Hyperthermia. Pt
s fever curve as decreased slightly, however tmax
   still >103F.
   - likely source is infectious- [**Year (4 digits) 476**] known to cause prolonged high
   fevers and course is known to be more severe in HIV positive patients
   however fevers are of impressive duration and severity.  Warrants probe
   for alternative sources of which he has many:
   - ID consulted, appreciate their input. Rec imaging sinuses and torso
   with CT (look for cavitary lesions in lungs, sinuses to look for
   extrapulmonary [**Year (4 digits) 476**], abd to look for other abscess, necrotizing
   pancreatitis).
   - continue levaquin for PNA
   -  found to have DVT in R popliteal/superficial femoral.  s/p IVC
   filter
   - ATC tylenol
   - cooling blankets PRN
   4. Acute Kidney Injury- urine sediment with casts c/w ATN, low SG c/w
   poor concentrating ability.  Cr down slightly to 3.5, persistently
   uremic. No hyperkalemia, still making urine, no indication for dialysis
   at present.
   - cont to monitor.
   - will renally dose medications.
   - started calcium carbonate for calcium/phos product >50 with good
   response.
   5. Hypernatremia- likely in the setting of diuresis and had been NPO
   - Free h20 deficit ~5L, did not respond to free h20 flushes, may not be
   absorbing adequately from GI tract.  Will give D5W, recheck lytes in pm
   and adjust free water repletion accordingly.
   - stopped lasix gtt
   6. HIV- hold HAART for now; low VL and high CD4

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of HIV, Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), and now acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to Legionella pneumonia. He has developed disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right lower extremity, and acute kidney injury (AKI). He is also experiencing hyperthermia, hypernatremia, and elevated pancreatic enzymes. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's ARDS and DVT may lead to further respiratory failure, requiring increased ventilator support or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient's fevers, DIC, and AKI suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated pancreatic enzymes may indicate pancreatitis, which can progress to necrotizing pancreatitis and potentially lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
4. Kidney Injury: The patient's AKI may worsen, requiring dialysis and potentially leading to chronic kidney disease.
5. Thromboembolic Events: The patient's DVT and DIC may increase the risk of further thromboembolic events, such as pulmonary embolism or stroke.
6. Infection: The patient's HIV and PCP history, combined with his current respiratory failure and AKI, make him susceptible to secondary infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's HIV and PCP history may increase the risk of neurological complications, such as encephalopathy or seizures.
8. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's DIC and AKI may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrest or myocardial infarction.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's hypernatremia and AKI may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
10. Ongoing Infections: The patient's ongoing fevers and elevated inflammatory markers suggest the possibility of ongoing infections, which may require further antibiotic therapy and monitoring.

t with

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, history of PCP pneumonia, now presenting with ARDS and DIC. He has developed DVT in his right leg and has been treated with an IVC filter. He has been experiencing fever, hypoxia, and respiratory acidosis, and has been receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50%. His laboratory results show elevated D-dimer and fibrinogen levels, indicating ongoing DIC. He has also developed acute kidney injury, hypernatremia, and hypotension.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS is likely to progress, and he may require further increases in oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis and DIC: The patient's DIC is ongoing, and he may require further treatment with anticoagulants and platelet transfusions.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he may require further treatment with dialysis.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, and he may require further treatment with diuretics and electrolyte replacement.
5. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he may require further treatment with vasopressors and fluids.
6. DVT: The patient's DVT may progress, and he may require further treatment with anticoagulants and compression stockings.
7. HIV-related complications: The patient's HIV may be complicated by opportunistic infections, and he may require further treatment with antiretroviral therapy.

Assessment and plan:

1. Respiratory status: The patient's respiratory status is positive, and he will continue to receive mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50%.
2. Sepsis and DIC: The patient will continue to receive treatment with antibiotics and anticoagulants, and his laboratory results will be closely monitored.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient will continue to receive treatment with dialysis, and his electrolyte levels will be closely monitored.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient will continue to receive treatment with diuretics and electrolyte replacement, and his sodium level will be closely monitored.
5. Hypotension: The patient will continue to receive treatment with vasopressors and fluids, and his blood pressure will be closely monitored.
6. DVT: The patient will continue to receive treatment with anticoagulants and compression stockings, and his DVT will be closely monitored.
7. HIV-related complications: The patient will continue to receive treatment with antiretroviral therapy, and his HIV will be closely monitored.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment of his various medical complications to prevent further deterioration and improve his chances of recovery.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, a history of PCP pneumonia, and currently diagnosed with ARDS and DIC. He has developed a DVT in his right lower extremity and has undergone placement of an IVC filter. The patient's respiratory status has improved, with decreased FiO2 and increased PaO2. He continues to receive pentobarbital for sedation and is being weaned off the ventilator.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (14.1)
* Decreased platelet count (111)
* Elevated creatinine (3.8)
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (647 IU/L)
* Elevated D-dimer (7462 ng/mL)
* Elevated troponin-T (0.09)
* Elevated lipase (647 IU/L)

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 103.6°F
* Heart rate: 76 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 134/71 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 0 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 93%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Scleral edema
* Small ecchymotic area on the right cheek
* Coarse mechanical breath sounds bilaterally
* Slightly distended abdomen
* 1+ bilateral lower extremity edema

The patient's laboratory results and physical examination findings suggest the following potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis/DIC: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, decreased platelet count, and elevated D-dimer suggest ongoing sepsis. The patient's DIC is being managed with activated protein C, transfusions, and monitoring of laboratory results.
2. Hyperthermia: The patient's temperature is elevated, and the source of the hyperthermia is likely infectious, possibly related to the patient's HIV infection or a superinfection.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and urine sediment with granular casts suggest acute kidney injury, likely related to sepsis.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's elevated sodium level is likely related to diuresis and NPO status.
5. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and the cause is unclear, but may be related to cardiac origin, septic shock, or volume overload.
6. HIV: The patient's low viral load and high CD4 count suggest that he is not actively infected with HIV, and HAART should be held for now.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and his disposition is ICU level of care.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's ARDS has worsened, and they are experiencing decreased tidal volumes, which may lead to further respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's persistent fevers, despite antibiotic treatment, and the presence of pan-cultured bacteria, raise concerns about extrapulmonary sources of infection, which can lead to sepsis.
3. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): The patient's laboratory results show elevated D-dimer levels, which may indicate DIC. This can lead to bleeding complications and organ dysfunction.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's ARF, which is characterized by ATN with casts, may worsen if not managed properly.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's serum sodium levels are elevated, which can lead to complications such as seizures, coma, and even death if not corrected.
6. Pancreatic Enzyme Elevation: The patient's elevated pancreatic enzymes may indicate pancreatic damage or inflammation, which can lead to complications such as pancreatitis.
7. Limb Ischemia: The patient's DIC and low flow state may contribute to limb ischemia, which can lead to tissue necrosis and gangrene.
8. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's tube feeds may not be providing adequate nutrition, which can lead to malnutrition and impaired wound healing.

To address these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal function. The patient's antibiotic treatment should be reassessed, and additional antibiotics may be necessary to address potential extrapulmonary sources of infection. The patient's DIC should be managed with anticoagulation therapy, and their hypernatremia should be corrected with IV fluids. The patient's pancreatic enzyme elevation should be further evaluated to determine the underlying cause. The patient's limb ischemia should be managed with aggressive wound care and consideration of revascularization procedures. Finally, the patient's nutritional status should be closely monitored, and additional nutritional support may be necessary to prevent malnutrition.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, history of PCP pneumonia, now presenting with ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He is sedated and intubated, receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 22 cmH2O. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 102.2°F, heart rate of 100 bpm, and blood pressure of 152/83 mmHg. His respiratory status is improving, with a PaO2 of 214 mmHg and a PCO2 of 42 mmHg.

The patient has several laboratory abnormalities, including hypernatremia, hyperglycemia, and elevated pancreatic enzymes. He is also experiencing acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL and urine sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis. His coagulation profile is abnormal, with a prolonged INR and decreased fibrinogen level.

The patient's medical conditions include:

1. ARDS: The patient has severe respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and high levels of oxygen supplementation.
2. DIC: The patient has a prolonged INR and decreased fibrinogen level, consistent with disseminated intravascular coagulation.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has elevated pancreatic enzymes and is at risk for necrotizing pancreatitis.
4. Hyperthermia: The patient's temperature is elevated, despite antibiotics, and may be due to an infectious source or other underlying condition.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient has a creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL and urine sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient has a sodium level of 152 mmol/L, which is likely due to diuresis and inadequate free water repletion.
7. HIV: The patient has a low viral load and high CD4 count, and is not currently receiving HAART.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure and potential need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hyperthermia and elevated pancreatic enzymes may indicate an underlying septic process, which could lead to further organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to necrotizing pancreatitis and potential need for surgical intervention.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's DIC may worsen, leading to bleeding complications or further organ dysfunction.
6. HIV-related complications: The patient's HIV may lead to further complications, such as opportunistic infections or malignancies.

t with

d vancomycin, cefepime, azithromycin.

   - cont nebs

   [**4-25**]).  Unclear precipitant for pancreatitis. Has not been on propofol

s fever curve as decreased slightly, however tmax

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, history of PCP pneumonia, and currently diagnosed with ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He is in the ICU for respiratory support and management of his conditions. The patient's respiratory status has improved over the past 24 hours, but he is still hypoxic and requires increased FiO2. He has elevated pancreatic enzymes, and the cause of pancreatitis is unclear. The patient is also experiencing hyperthermia, with a temperature above 103°F, and has a fever curve that has not improved despite antibiotics. He has acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 3.5 mg/dL, and is experiencing hypernatremia, with a sodium level of 152 mmol/L. The patient is also experiencing symptoms of DIC, including symmetric distal extremity ischemia, and has an IVC filter placed for DVT.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is still compromised, and he may require further respiratory support, including mechanical ventilation.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is severe, and he may require further management, including nutrition support and management of electrolyte imbalances.
3. Hyperthermia: The patient's fever curve has not improved despite antibiotics, and he may require further management, including cooling blankets and antipyretics.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he may require further management, including dialysis.
5. DIC: The patient's symptoms of DIC are severe, and he may require further management, including anticoagulation therapy and transfusions.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, and he may require further management, including fluid repletion and electrolyte monitoring.
7. HIV: The patient's HIV infection is not well-controlled, and he may require further management, including antiretroviral therapy and monitoring of his viral load and CD4 count.

Recommendations:

1. Continue respiratory support, including mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Manage pancreatitis with nutrition support, electrolyte monitoring, and management of pancreatic enzymes.
3. Manage hyperthermia with cooling blankets, antipyretics, and further evaluation for alternative sources of fever.
4. Manage acute kidney injury with fluid repletion, electrolyte monitoring, and consideration of dialysis.
5. Manage DIC with anticoagulation therapy, transfusions, and further evaluation for underlying causes.
6. Manage hypernatremia with fluid repletion, electrolyte monitoring, and management of sodium levels.
7. Manage HIV infection with antiretroviral therapy, monitoring of viral load and CD4 count, and further evaluation for opportunistic infections.

   - Appreciate ID input, pt currently on levaquin for [**Name Initial (PRE) 476**], per
   their recs have d/c
d vancomycin, cefepime, azithromycin.
   - Had mini BAL yesterday, gram stain unremarkable, continue to follow
   up results.
   - cont acetaminophen for fever- still continues to spike despite
   antibiotics
   - cont nebs
   - resend sputum given temperature
   #Elevated pancreatic enzymes. Markedly elevated from prior (normal
   [**4-25**]).  Unclear precipitant for pancreatitis. Has not been on propofol
   for some time.  Given pt has HIV, is at risk for extrapulmonary
   manifestations of legionellosis, ? unknown if this has been known to
   affect pancreas.
   -literature search for current meds, risk for pancreatitis (xigris,
   pentobarbital)
   -Monitor hemodynamics, aggressive fluid rescusitation if needed for
   third spacing, caution for now given respiratory status.
   -Continue trophic feeds via NGT, do not advance for now.
   -Continue to monitor Ca, HCT, hemodynamics.
   -Necrotizing pancreatitis may be etiology for fevers, pt currently not
   stable enough for CT, but should consider when possible. Discuss with
   ID need to start meropenem.
   -continue to trenf enzymes
   2. ?DIC.  DIC frequently described sequelae of legionellosis.  Pt has
   had abnormalities in his DIC panel as well as a confusing picture of
   symmetric distal extremity ischemia,  more consistent in appearance
   with vasoocclusion related to pressors (which pt has not received)
   rather than DIC/microangiopathic thrombosis.  The magnitide of the
   digital ischemia is out of proportion to the degree of abnormality of
   DIC. Also on ddx is croglobulinema, pt has HIV which has not been
   associated with increased incidence of DIC, unlike HCV. No known
   history of HCV, last serology here [**2101**].
   - cont to monitor labs; fibrinogen improved this AM
   - cont activated protein C, will have completed today at 1700
   - transfusion parameters- if Hct<25, cryo for fibrinogen <100, plts if
   less than 35 though may worsen coagulopathy.
   - No need for anticoagulation at this time.  Had IVC filter placed
   yesterday for DVT
   - continue to monitor exam, call vascular surgery if pt develops
   evidence for wet gangrene that could be fuelling sepsis.
   -f/u cryoglobulins (send yesterday, a send out, should take ~10 days)
   -check HCV serology
   3. Hyperthermia. Pt
s fever curve as decreased slightly, however tmax
   still >103F.
   - likely source is infectious- [**Year (4 digits) 476**] known to cause prolonged high
   fevers and course is known to be more severe in HIV positive patients
   however fevers are of impressive duration and severity.  Warrants probe
   for alternative sources of which he has many:
   - ID consulted, appreciate their input. Rec imaging sinuses and torso
   with CT (look for cavitary lesions in lungs, sinuses to look for
   extrapulmonary [**Year (4 digits) 476**], abd to look for other abscess, necrotizing
   pancreatitis).
   - continue levaquin for PNA
   -  found to have DVT in R popliteal/superficial femoral.  s/p IVC
   filter
   - ATC tylenol
   - cooling blankets PRN
   4. Acute Kidney Injury- urine sediment with casts c/w ATN, low SG c/w
   poor concentrating ability.  Cr down slightly to 3.5, persistently
   uremic. No hyperkalemia, still making urine, no indication for dialysis
   at present.
   - cont to monitor.
   - will renally dose medications.
   - started calcium carbonate for calcium/phos product >50 with good
   response.
   5. Hypernatremia- likely in the setting of diuresis and had been NPO
   - Free h20 deficit ~5L, did not respond to free h20 flushes, may not be
   absorbing adequately from GI tract.  Will give D5W, recheck lytes in pm
   and adjust free water repletion accordingly.
   - stopped lasix gtt
   6. HIV- hold HAART for now; low VL and high CD4
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, history of PCP pneumonia, and currently diagnosed with ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 22 cmH2O. He has been treated with antibiotics, including cefepime, azithromycin, and levofloxacin, but his fever remains elevated. His pancreatic enzymes are markedly elevated, and he has been diagnosed with pancreatitis. He has also been diagnosed with DIC, which is a complication of legionellosis. His coagulation parameters are abnormal, and he has been treated with activated protein C and transfusions. He has also developed distal extremity ischemia, which is thought to be related to pressors rather than DIC.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis is severe, and he is at risk for necrotizing pancreatitis, which can lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
3. DIC: The patient's DIC is severe, and he is at risk for further bleeding and coagulopathy.
4. Hyperthermia: The patient's fever is persistent, and he is at risk for further complications, including sepsis and multi-organ failure.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's kidney function is impaired, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, and he is at risk for further complications, including seizures and coma.
7. HIV: The patient's HIV infection is not well-controlled, and he is at risk for further complications, including opportunistic infections and cancer.

ICU Care Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation with FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 22 cmH2O.
2. Continue antibiotics, including levofloxacin, and monitor for signs of infection.
3. Continue treatment for pancreatitis, including nasogastric suction and bowel rest.
4. Continue treatment for DIC, including activated protein C and transfusions.
5. Monitor for signs of hyperthermia, including fever and tachycardia, and treat with antipyretics and cooling blankets as needed.
6. Monitor for signs of acute kidney injury, including oliguria and azotemia, and treat with diuretics and dialysis as needed.
7. Monitor for signs of hypernatremia, including seizures and coma, and treat with fluids and electrolyte replacement as needed.
8. Continue HIV treatment, including antiretroviral therapy, and monitor for signs of opportunistic infections and cancer.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, history of PCP pneumonia, and currently diagnosed with ARDS, DIC, and ARF. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, with a fever of 102.2°F (39°C). His respiratory status is stable, with a PCV mode on the ventilator. He has a distended abdomen and scrotal edema. His laboratory results show elevated pancreatic enzymes, and his microbiology results are pending. He has a history of C. difficile infection and is being treated with antibiotics.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may progress, leading to further respiratory failure and the need for more aggressive ventilator support.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated pancreatic enzymes may indicate pancreatitis, which could lead to further complications, such as necrosis or abscesses.
3. Sepsis: The patient's persistent fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
4. DIC: The patient's DIC may worsen, leading to further bleeding complications and organ dysfunction.
5. ARF: The patient's ARF may progress, leading to further kidney damage and the need for dialysis.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may worsen, leading to further complications, such as seizures or coma.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition may worsen, leading to further complications, such as weakness, fatigue, and impaired wound healing.
8. Infection: The patient's pending microbiology results may indicate a new infection, which could lead to further complications, such as sepsis or organ dysfunction.

Based on the patient's current status and potential complications, it is recommended that he continue to receive aggressive medical treatment, including antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals as necessary. He should also be closely monitored for signs of respiratory failure, pancreatitis, sepsis, DIC, ARF, hypernatremia, malnutrition, and infection.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of HIV and PCP pneumonia, currently diagnosed with ARDS and suspected to have DIC.

The patient's respiratory status has continued to improve over the past 24 hours, with decreasing FiO2 requirement and resolution of hypercarbia and acidosis at the same pressure settings. However, this morning, the patient became acutely hypoxic with decreasing tidal volume. The likely causes are positional atelectasis, mucous plugging, or airway obstruction.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 102.2°F (39°C)
* Heart rate: 95 bpm (62-100 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 144/77 mmHg (96-160/86 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 280 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* SpO2: 97%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.4-15.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 10.1-11.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 150-163 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.5-3.0 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.09 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.4 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.4 g/dL
* Calcium: 8.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.9 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical history includes HIV, PCP pneumonia, and a recent diagnosis of ARDS with suspected DIC.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS is a life-threatening condition that requires close monitoring and management.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death.
3. DIC: The patient's suspected DIC can lead to bleeding complications, organ failure, and death.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's recent diagnosis of ARDS and PCP pneumonia increases the risk of developing pneumonia, which can be life-threatening.
5. Hypoxemia: The patient's acute hypoxia this morning suggests the possibility of hypoxemia, which can lead to organ failure and death.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his respiratory status, fluid balance, and laboratory results. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the patient is unlikely to tolerate bronch or ETT switch.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of HIV, PCP pneumonia, and now ARDS in the setting of DIC and ARF. He is intubated and sedated, with a fever of 102.2°F. He has a history of acute loss of tidal volumes, which resolved with suctioning. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 95 bpm, blood pressure of 144/77 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. His respiratory support includes a ventilator mode of PCV+Assist, with a peak inspiratory pressure of 45 cmH2O and a positive end-expiratory pressure of 22 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, with a differential count showing 81.0% neutrophils, 4.0% bands, and 6.0% lymphocytes. His liver function tests are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 102 IU/L and an alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level of 58 IU/L. His renal function tests are also elevated, with a creatinine level of 3.5 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 15.1 mL/min/1.73 m². His electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a sodium level of 151 mmol/L, a potassium level of 4.0 mmol/L, and a calcium level of 8.1 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS is a significant risk factor for respiratory failure, and his ventilator settings may need to be adjusted to optimize oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Pancreatic necrosis: The patient's elevated pancreatic enzymes and abdominal tenderness suggest the possibility of pancreatic necrosis, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
4. DIC: The patient's DIC could lead to bleeding complications, such as hematuria or melena, and could also increase the risk of respiratory failure.
5. ARF: The patient's ARF could lead to acute kidney injury, which could increase the risk of sepsis and multi-organ failure.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia could lead to central nervous system complications, such as seizures or coma, and could also increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition could lead to weakness, fatigue, and increased risk of infection.
8. Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility and malnutrition could increase the risk of pressure ulcers.
9. DVT: The patient's immobility and malnutrition could increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
10. VAP: The patient's immobility and malnutrition could increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of HIV, PCP pneumonia, and pancreatitis, currently presenting with ARDS and DIC. The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 102.2°F (39°C)
* Heart rate: 85 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 109/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 0 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a PCV+Assist mode, with a peak inspiratory pressure of 41 cmH2O and a plateau pressure of 34 cmH2O. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.34, PCO2 of 48 mmHg, and PO2 of 99 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 15.1 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 163 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 24 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.4 g/dL
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.8 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* ARDS
* DIC
* Pancreatitis
* HIV
* PCP pneumonia

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with a PCV+Assist mode
* Antibiotics for pneumonia
* Anticoagulation therapy for DIC
* Pain management with acetaminophen and fentanyl
* Nutritional support with TPN and fiber supplements
* Blood product transfusions as needed
* Monitoring for hyperthermia and hypernatremia

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to ARDS and mechanical ventilation
* Sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction due to DIC and pancreatitis
* Pancreatitis-related complications such as necrotizing pancreatitis and pancreatic abscess
* HIV-related complications such as opportunistic infections and malignancies
* Antiretroviral therapy-related side effects

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and his disposition is ICU care.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, a history of PCP pneumonia, and current ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 102.2°F, heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 109/58 mmHg. His respiratory status is stable, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 248. His laboratory results show elevated pancreatic enzymes, with a possibility of necrotizing pancreatitis. He has also developed DIC, with an INR improving. His kidney function is impaired, with acute kidney injury and hypernatremia. He is receiving TPN and has a central line, arterial line, and multi-lumen line. His code status is DNR.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and DIC may worsen his respiratory status, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may progress to necrotizing pancreatitis, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
3. DIC: The patient's DIC may worsen, leading to bleeding complications and organ failure.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to end-stage renal disease.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to seizures, brain damage, and other complications.
6. HIV-related complications: The patient's HIV may lead to opportunistic infections and other complications.
7. Sepsis: The patient's fevers and elevated white blood cell count may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
8. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation may increase his risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
9. Catheter-related bloodstream infections: The patient's central line and arterial line may increase his risk of catheter-related bloodstream infections.
10. Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility and mechanical ventilation may increase his risk of pressure ulcers.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, a history of PCP pneumonia, and is currently diagnosed with ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He is sedated and has a fever of 102.2°F (39°C). His respiratory status is positive for ARDS, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 248, indicating a moderate level of hypoxemia. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 18 cmH2O and FiO2 of 40%.

The patient's cardiac status is stable, with a heart rate of 85 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 109/58 mmHg. His renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 2.4 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 28.2 mL/min. He is also experiencing acute kidney injury (AKI) with a urine sediment consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

The patient's pancreatic enzymes are markedly elevated, indicating pancreatitis. His calcium levels are slightly low, but he is receiving calcium carbonate supplementation. He has a history of hyperthermia, which is likely related to an infectious source.

The patient has a DVT in his right popliteal/superficial femoral vein and has been placed on an IVC filter. He is also at risk for hypernatremia due to his pancreatitis and is receiving free water flushes to replete his deficit.

The patient's HIV status is being managed with antiretroviral therapy (HAART), which has been held for now due to his low viral load and high CD4 count. His CD4 count is 14.0 K/uL, and his viral load is undetectable.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to respiratory failure, which could require invasive mechanical ventilation.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to necrotizing pancreatitis, which could increase his risk of sepsis and multi-organ failure.
3. DIC: The patient's DIC may worsen, leading to bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding, hematuria, and hemoptysis.
4. AKI: The patient's AKI may worsen, leading to acute kidney failure, which could require dialysis.
5. Hyperthermia: The patient's hyperthermia may worsen, leading to heat stroke, which could be life-threatening.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may worsen, leading to seizures, coma, and death.
7. HIV-related complications: The patient's HIV may lead to opportunistic infections, such as PCP pneumonia, and other complications, such as lipodystrophy and wasting syndrome.

To mitigate these risks, the patient will require close monitoring and aggressive management of his respiratory, cardiac, renal, and pancreatic status. He will also require ongoing antiretroviral therapy and prophylaxis for opportunistic infections.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, history of PCP pneumonia, and current ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. The patient is experiencing a high fever, which is not responding to antibiotics, and has a white blood cell count of 14.0 x 10^9/L. The patient's respiratory status is positive, with a positive PCP result, and the patient is being weaned off mechanical ventilation.

The patient has a history of pancreatitis, which is ongoing, and is being treated with heparin for DVT. The patient has a central line, arterial line, and a urinary catheter. The patient is receiving TPN with lipids and replete with fiber.

The patient's laboratory results show a high white blood cell count, high creatinine, and high lactate dehydrogenase. The patient's electrolytes are abnormal, with a high sodium level and a low potassium level.

The patient's medical history includes HIV, PCP pneumonia, and pancreatitis. The patient's current medications include levofloxacin, pentobarbital, fentanyl, and midazolam.

The patient's physical examination is abnormal, with a temperature of 104.5°F (40.3°C), a heart rate of 100 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 123/62 mmHg. The patient's lung sounds are abnormal, with bilateral wheezing and crackles.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Continue weaning off mechanical ventilation
* Continue antibiotics for PCP
* Continue heparin for DVT
* Continue TPN with lipids and replete with fiber
* Continue monitoring for pancreatitis and DIC
* Continue monitoring for respiratory failure
* Continue monitoring for hyperthermia
* Continue monitoring for acute kidney injury
* Continue monitoring for hypernatremia
* Continue HIV treatment
* Continue prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Pancreatitis
* DIC
* Hyperthermia
* Acute kidney injury
* Hypernatremia
* HIV-related complications

The patient's potential surgical complications include:

* Necrotizing pancreatitis
* Abdominal abscess
* Hemorrhagic pancreatitis

The patient's potential medical imaging complications include:

* CT scan with contrast
* MRI with contrast
* Ultrasound with contrast

The patient's potential laboratory complications include:

* Blood cultures
* Urine cultures
* Blood gas analysis
* Electrolyte panel

* Renal function tests

The patient's potential medication complications include:

* Antibiotics
* Antivirals
* Anti-HIV medications
* Pain medications
* Sedatives
* Anti-anxiety medications
* Antihistamines
* Anti-inflammatory medications

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, a history of PCP pneumonia, and currently presents with ARDS, pancreatitis, and DIC. He has been experiencing high fevers, hypotension, and respiratory acidosis. His respiratory status is positive, and he is on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 14 and FiO2 of 50%. He has a moderate-sized right-to-left pleural effusion and is at risk for further complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and hypoxemia may worsen if his respiratory status is not closely monitored and managed.
2. Sepsis: The patient's high fevers, hypotension, and leukocytosis suggest sepsis, which may be caused by a variety of sources, including pneumonia, pancreatitis, or central line infections.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as abscesses, hemorrhage, or necrosis.
4. DIC: The patient's DIC may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further bleeding complications.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if not managed properly, leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
6. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances or need for dialysis.
7. Hyperthermia: The patient's hyperthermia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as organ dysfunction or failure.
8. HIV-related complications: The patient's HIV infection may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as opportunistic infections or immune dysfunction.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
2. Start vancomycin and cefipime for broad-spectrum coverage for possible sepsis.
3. Continue to manage the patient's pancreatitis with tube feeds and titrate up to goal per nutrition.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's DIC and adjust treatment as needed.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with fluid resuscitation and vasopressors as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's acute kidney injury and adjust treatment as needed.
7. Continue to manage the patient's hyperthermia with cooling blankets and acetaminophen as needed.
8. Continue to manage the patient's HIV infection with antiretroviral therapy as needed.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Complications:
	* ARDS may worsen due to continued fevers and high PEEP settings.
	* Pneumonia may not be ruled out, and the patient may require further evaluation and treatment.
	* The patient's respiratory status is positive, and the PCP negative overnight suggests that the etiology of the respiratory distress may be related to the ET tube rather than a primary pulmonary process.
2. Pancreatitis:
	* The patient's pancreatic enzymes are markedly elevated, and the etiology is unclear.
	* Necrotizing pancreatitis may be a contributing factor to the patient's fevers and respiratory distress.
	* The patient's pancreatic enzymes will need to be trended and monitored closely.
3. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC):
	* The patient's INR is improving, but the patient is still at risk for bleeding due to the ongoing coagulopathy.
	* The patient's platelet count is low, and the patient may require further transfusions.
	* The patient's fibrinogen level is low, and the patient may require cryoprecipitate transfusions.
4. Hyperthermia:
	* The patient's fevers are of impressive duration and severity, and the patient may require further evaluation to identify alternative sources of infection.
	* The patient's ID consultant has recommended imaging of the sinuses and torso to evaluate for potential sources of infection.
5. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):
	* The patient's urine sediment shows casts consistent with ATN, and the patient's creatinine is improving.
	* The patient may require further monitoring and potential dialysis if the creatinine continues to rise.
6. Hypernatremia:
	* The patient's free water deficit is improving, and the patient will require further fluid resuscitation in the setting of pancreatitis.
7. HIV:
	* The patient's HAART will be held for now due to the patient's low VL and high CD4 count.

The patient's ongoing treatment plan includes:

* Continuing to wean pentobarbital and switching to midazolam and fentanyl to prevent dysynchrony.
* Monitoring the patient's respiratory status and adjusting PEEP settings as tolerated.
* Continuing antibiotics and antifungal therapy.
* Monitoring the patient's pancreatic enzymes and trended.
* Evaluating the patient's ID consultant's recommendations for imaging and further evaluation.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's coagulopathy and bleeding risk.
* Providing further fluid resuscitation and electrolyte management as needed.
* Monitoring the patient's AKI and potential need for dialysis.
* Holding HAART for now due to the patient's low VL and high CD4 count.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, history of PCP pneumonia, and currently experiencing ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. The patient's condition is complex, and multiple medical complications are present.

1. Respiratory Status: The patient has ARDS with respiratory acidosis, and his oxygenation is being maintained with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 14 cmH2O. The patient is on weaning protocol for sedation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is attributed to sepsis, poor cardiac output, and intravascular volume depletion. The patient is receiving vanco/cefipime for broad-spectrum coverage, and fluid boluses are being administered to maintain a MAP >65.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has elevated pancreatic enzymes, and the precipitant is unclear. The patient is receiving tube feeds and will continue to monitor calcium, HCT, and hemodynamics.
4. DIC: The patient has DIC, and his INR is improving. The patient is not receiving anticoagulation therapy, and his HCT will be monitored.
5. Hyperthermia: The patient's fever is persisting despite antibiotic therapy, and a source is being investigated. The patient is receiving levaquin for PNA, and vanco/cefipime will be restarted for broad-spectrum coverage.
6. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient has acute kidney injury with urine sediment consistent with ATN. His creatinine is improving, and there is no indication for dialysis at present.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, and his free H2O deficit is improving. He will continue to receive free H2O flushes and his lasix gtt will be stopped.
8. HIV: The patient's HIV treatment will be held for now, as his viral load is low and CD4 count is high.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress, leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to organ failure and sepsis.
* DIC: The patient's DIC may worsen, leading to bleeding and organ failure.
* Hyperthermia: The patient's hyperthermia may lead to organ failure and death.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to chronic kidney disease and dialysis dependence.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to seizures, coma, and death.
* HIV: The patient's HIV may progress, leading to opportunistic infections and AIDS.

Based on the patient's complex condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and metabolic status. Multidisciplinary care, including input from infectious disease, nephrology, and cardiology, will be necessary to optimize the patient's care.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, a history of PCP pneumonia, ARDS, and pancreatitis, who is currently in the ICU. He has been experiencing high fevers, hypotension, and respiratory distress. He has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin and cefepime, and has had a central line placed. He has also had a pleural effusion drained and has been receiving mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's high fevers and hypotension may be indicative of sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated pancreatic enzymes may indicate ongoing pancreatitis, which can lead to further complications, such as sepsis and multi-organ failure.
4. DIC: The patient's elevated D-dimer and low platelet count may indicate disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which can lead to bleeding and organ failure.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and low urine output may indicate acute kidney injury, which can lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
6. Hyperthermia: The patient's continued high fevers may indicate hyperthermia, which can lead to further complications, such as seizures and organ failure.
7. HIV-Related Complications: The patient's HIV infection may lead to further complications, such as opportunistic infections and immune system dysfunction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy and monitor for signs of sepsis.
2. Maintain mechanical ventilation and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
3. Monitor pancreatic enzymes and consider further treatment for pancreatitis.
4. Monitor platelet count and consider further treatment for DIC.
5. Monitor kidney function and consider further treatment for acute kidney injury.
6. Monitor for signs of hyperthermia and consider further treatment.
7. Consider further treatment for HIV-related complications, such as antiretroviral therapy and prophylactic antibiotics.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, history of PCP pneumonia, ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He is currently in the ICU with severe respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 14. His temperature is elevated at 102.4°F (39.1°C), and he has been experiencing high fevers despite antibiotics. He has a moderate-sized right-to-left pleural effusion and is at risk for respiratory acidosis.

The patient's lab results show elevated pancreatic enzymes, with a significant increase from his prior levels. The cause of pancreatitis is unclear, but it may be medication-induced or related to hypotension. He has also been experiencing hypotension, which may be due to sepsis, poor cardiac output, or intravascular volume depletion.

The patient's coagulation profile shows a prolonged INR, and he has been receiving anticoagulation therapy. However, his platelet count is low, and he has been bleeding from his central line site. He has also developed a DVT in his right popliteal and superficial femoral veins.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further interventions to improve his oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated temperature and white blood cell count suggest that he may be septic, which could lead to further complications such as organ failure and death.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated pancreatic enzymes suggest that he may have pancreatitis, which could lead to further complications such as organ failure and death.
4. DIC: The patient's coagulation profile shows a prolonged INR, which could lead to further bleeding complications.
5. DVT: The patient's DVT in his right popliteal and superficial femoral veins could lead to further complications such as pulmonary embolism and death.
6. Hyperthermia: The patient's elevated temperature could lead to further complications such as organ failure and death.
7. Acute kidney injury: The patient's urine sediment shows casts consistent with ATN, which could lead to further complications such as chronic kidney disease and death.
8. Hypernatremia: The patient's elevated sodium levels could lead to further complications such as seizures and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide further interventions as needed to improve his oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Consider further antibiotics to treat the patient's suspected sepsis.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's pancreatic enzymes and consider further interventions to treat pancreatitis.
4. Monitor the patient's coagulation profile and bleeding complications, and consider further interventions to treat DIC.
5. Monitor the patient's DVT and consider further interventions to prevent pulmonary embolism.
6. Consider further interventions to treat the patient's hyperthermia, such as cooling blankets or acetaminophen.
7. Monitor the patient's urine output and consider further interventions to treat acute kidney injury.
8. Monitor the patient's sodium levels and consider further interventions to treat hypernatremia.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, history of PCP pneumonia, ARDS, and pancreatitis, currently in the ICU with severe sepsis, hypotension, and respiratory failure. He has a pleural effusion, elevated pancreatic enzymes, and is experiencing hyperthermia. The patient has a complex medical history, including a recent episode of DIC, and is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressors, and nutritional support.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, with elevated temperatures and respiratory acidosis. Weaning from mechanical ventilation may be challenging, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's high fevers and hypotension suggest sepsis, which may be caused by a variety of factors, including pneumonia, pancreatitis, or other sources of infection.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated pancreatic enzymes suggest ongoing pancreatitis, which may be caused by medication, hypotension, or other factors.
4. DIC: The patient's history of DIC and current coagulopathy pose a risk for bleeding complications, and close monitoring of coagulation parameters is necessary.
5. Hyperthermia: The patient's persistent high fevers despite antibiotics suggest an ongoing infectious process, which may be caused by a variety of factors, including pneumonia, pancreatitis, or other sources of infection.
6. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's urine sediment with casts c/w ATN suggests acute kidney injury, which may be caused by sepsis, pancreatitis, or other factors.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's free water deficit is improving, but close monitoring is necessary to prevent hypernatremia.
8. HIV: The patient's low VL and high CD4 count suggest that HAART may not be necessary at this time, but close monitoring of his HIV status is necessary.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics and vasopressors to manage sepsis and hypotension.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider weaning from mechanical ventilation.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's pancreatic enzymes and consider further evaluation for pancreatitis.
4. Monitor the patient's coagulation parameters closely and consider transfusions as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and consider further evaluation for hyperthermia.
6. Monitor the patient's kidney function closely and consider further evaluation for acute kidney injury.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's sodium levels and consider further evaluation for hypernatremia.
8. Monitor the patient's HIV status closely and consider restarting HAART if necessary.

Further Evaluation:

1. Mini-BAL results are pending, and the patient's pleural effusion should be evaluated further.
2. The patient's central line site should be changed, and consideration should be given to TEE to evaluate for endocarditis.
3. The patient's CT head should be evaluated to rule out central sources of infection.
4. The patient's pancreatitis should be further evaluated to determine the cause and optimal treatment.
5. The patient's coagulopathy should be further evaluated to determine the optimal treatment.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, a history of PCP pneumonia, and currently suffering from ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He has been experiencing a fever of 103.2°F, which has persisted despite antibiotics. His respiratory status is positive, with a PaO2 of 200, and he is on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 14 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. He has a moderate-sized right-sided pleural effusion, which is being evaluated for possible thoracentesis.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of white blood cells, platelets, and lactate dehydrogenase, as well as increased levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and liver enzymes. His coagulation profile is abnormal, with an INR of 1.3 and a partial thromboplastin time of 33.7 seconds.

The patient's physical examination reveals tachycardia, distant heart sounds, coarse mechanical breath sounds bilaterally, and upper airway secretions. He has also developed 1+ bilateral lower extremity edema, with dusky appearing digits and toes.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory status: Weaning of ventilator support and possible decrease in FiO2.
* Hyperthermia: Continued antibiotics and acetaminophen for fever management.
* Hypotension: Possible sepsis, poor cardiac output, or intravascular volume depletion.
* DIC: Improving INR, but continued monitoring of coagulation profile.
* Acute kidney injury: Continued monitoring of urine output and electrolyte levels.
* Hypernatremia: Free water deficit improving, but continued monitoring of sodium levels.
* Elevated pancreatic enzymes: Possible medication-induced or hypotension-related.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis or septic shock due to persistent fever and abnormal laboratory results.
* Respiratory failure due to weaning of ventilator support.
* Cardiac complications due to tachycardia, poor cardiac output, or hypotension.
* Renal failure due to continued acute kidney injury.
* Gastrointestinal complications due to pancreatitis or medication-induced.
* Infectious complications due to possible sepsis or endocarditis.

Based on the patient's condition and laboratory results, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination. Close communication with the patient's family and healthcare team is also crucial to ensure that the patient receives appropriate care and treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, a history of PCP pneumonia, and current diagnoses of ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He is mechanically ventilated and receiving antibiotics, anticoagulation, and sedation. His fever has been spiking despite antibiotics, and his pleural effusion is moderate-sized. He has developed acute kidney injury with casts consistent with ATN, and his pancreatic enzymes are elevated. His HIV viral load is low, and his CD4 count is high, so HAART has been held.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's ARDS is likely to worsen his respiratory status, and he may require increased ventilator support or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest sepsis, which could worsen his condition and lead to organ failure.
3. DIC: The patient's DIC may worsen his bleeding risk and increase the risk of organ failure.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated pancreatic enzymes and lack of inciting factor suggest pancreatitis, which could lead to further organ dysfunction and failure.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen his fluid and electrolyte status, leading to further organ dysfunction and failure.
6. Hyperthermia: The patient's persistent fever may indicate a central source of infection, which could worsen his condition and lead to organ failure.
7. HIV-Associated Complications: The patient's HIV infection may increase his risk of opportunistic infections and organ dysfunction.
8. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia and distant heart sounds suggest cardiac dysfunction, which could worsen his condition and lead to organ failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider increasing ventilator support or ECMO if necessary.
3. Consider a central line re-site to reduce the risk of infection.
4. Monitor the patient's pleural effusion and consider thoracentesis if necessary.
5. Consider a CT scan of the head to evaluate for central source of infection.
6. Monitor the patient's pancreatic enzymes and consider further evaluation if necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function and consider dialysis if necessary.
8. Consider a cooling blanket to reduce the patient's fever.
9. Monitor the patient's HIV viral load and CD4 count, and consider restarting HAART if necessary.
10. Consider a multidisciplinary team approach to manage the patient's complex medical condition.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 50-year-old male with HIV, was admitted with ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He has been experiencing high fever, with temperatures reaching 103.2°F, and has been on antibiotics and antifungal therapy. The patient has been mechanically ventilated and has required sedation to manage his respiratory status.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 10.3 K/uL
* Hct: 25.4%
* Platelet count: 255 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.09 ng/mL
* ALT: 47 IU/L
* AST: 139 IU/L
* Amylase: 294 IU/L
* Lipase: 877 IU/L
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.4 g/dL
* LDH: 643 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* ARDS with respiratory failure
* DIC with coagulopathy
* Pancreatitis with elevated pancreatic enzymes
* HIV with low viral load and high CD4 count
* Hyperthermia with fever spike despite antibiotics
* Hypotension with ddx including sepsis, poor cardiac output, and intravascular volume depletion
* Acute kidney injury with urine sediment consistent with ATN
* Hypernatremia with free H2O deficit improving
* Elevated pancreatic enzymes with no inciting factor noted

The patient's current medications include:

* Levofloxacin
* Cefipime
* Vancomycin
* Midazolam
* Fentanyl
* Famotidine
* Pentobarbital
* Acetaminophen
* Nebulizers

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis with multi-organ failure
* Respiratory failure with need for mechanical ventilation
* Coagulopathy with bleeding risk
* Pancreatitis with potential for pancreatic necrosis
* Hyperthermia with risk of heat stroke
* Hypotension with risk of organ failure
* Acute kidney injury with risk of dialysis dependence
* Hypernatremia with risk of seizures
* Elevated pancreatic enzymes with risk of pancreatitis complications

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with FiO2 50% and PEEP 14
* Sedation with midazolam and fentanyl
* Antibiotics and antifungal therapy
* Anticoagulation therapy with warfarin
* Fluid management with IV fluids and diuretics
* Nutrition with TPN and tube feeds
* Glycemic control with insulin and glucose monitoring
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Close monitoring of laboratory results and clinical status.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 50-year-old male with HIV, a history of PCP pneumonia, and currently diagnosed with ARDS, DIC, and pancreatitis. He is admitted to the ICU with severe respiratory distress, fever, and coagulopathy.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a goal PaO2 >65, which is currently being met. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 14 and FiO2 of 50%. The plan is to wean the vent to a PEEP of 12 and decrease the FiO2 as tolerated.

The patient's fever continues to spike, despite antibiotic treatment, and is likely caused by an infectious source, possibly related to his HIV status. A CT scan of the sinuses and torso did not reveal a source of infection, but a pleural effusion was noted, which may be a potential source. The patient has also developed DVT in his right popliteal and superficial femoral veins, and an IVC filter has been placed.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of DIC, with an INR improving, and APC stopped. His kidney function is impaired, with acute kidney injury and urine sediment consistent with ATN. His pancreatic enzymes are elevated, but have improved.

The patient's medications include antibiotics, antivirals, and antifungals, as well as medications for pain and fever control. He is receiving total parenteral nutrition and has a central line.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and coagulopathy suggest a high risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
3. Hemorrhage: The patient's DIC and coagulopathy increase the risk of hemorrhage, which can be life-threatening.
4. Kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury and ATN increase the risk of kidney failure, which can require dialysis.
5. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated pancreatic enzymes and pancreatitis increase the risk of further organ dysfunction and death.
6. HIV-related complications: The patient's HIV status increases the risk of opportunistic infections and other complications, such as pneumocystis pneumonia and cryptococcal meningitis.
7. DVT and pulmonary embolism: The patient's DVT and IVC filter increase the risk of pulmonary embolism, which can be life-threatening.
8. Hyperthermia: The patient's fever and hyperthermia increase the risk of hyperthermia, which can be life-threatening.
9. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension and low blood pressure increase the risk of organ dysfunction and death.

Given the patient's complex condition, it is essential to continue monitoring his respiratory, cardiovascular, and kidney function, as well as his coagulopathy and HIV status. Further evaluation and treatment of his pleural effusion, DVT, and pancreatitis are also necessary to prevent complications and improve his outcomes.

   50 yo M  HIV, h/o PCP pneumonia, now ARDS [**2-20**] [**Month/Day (2) **] c/b DIC, [**Last Name (un) **],
   and pancreatitis
   #. Respiratory Status: [**Last Name (un) **] Positive.  PCP negative
   [**Name Initial (PRE) **] PEEP decreased to 14, FiO2 5o%.  With dysynchrony, patient become
   more acidemic; but with sedation, acidemia improving.
   - Will try to switch to AC today with FiO2 50%, PEEP 14, and TV around
   550 (which is what he
s doing now) to see if patient has less
   dysynchrony.  If ABG looks good, will then try to wean off
   pentobarbital and switch back to midaz/fentanyl.
   - goal PaO2 >65; currently patient meeting goal.
   - Appreciate ID input, pt currently on levaquin for [**Name Initial (PRE) 476**].  Will
   need to 2 more days
   - Mini-BAL results- NGTD.  PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 442**].
   - cont acetaminophen for fever- still continues to spike despite
   antibiotics
   - cont nebs
   - has moderate sized R>L pleural effusion.  Will ask IP to evaluate
   since patient is supine with difficult ventilation and difficult to
   visualize with ultrasound
   #. Hypotension: ddx includes sepsis, poor cardiac output, intravascular
   volume depletion [**2-20**] high fevers- improving now
   -  good UOP makes volume depletion less likely; last C.I. on vigileo
   was >3.
   -  cont vanco/cefipime for broad spectrum coverage for possible
   sepsis.  WBC maintaining despite high temperatures.
   #.  DIC.
   - INR now improving.
   - APC stopped on [**2106-5-1**]
   - transfusion parameters- if Hct<25, cryo for fibrinogen <100, plts if
   less than 35 though may worsen coagulopathy.
   - No need for anticoagulation at this time.  Had IVC filter placed for
   DVT.  Had blood in the ETT after starting heparin gtt for DVT; will
   hold for now and cont to monitor HCT
   - continue to monitor exam.  Appreciate vascular surgery- will likely
   need amputation in the future, but not at this time. Will continue to
   follow.
   -cryoglobulins and HCV- negative
   #. Hyperthermia. Continues to spike despite abx.
   - likely source is infectious vs central- [**Date Range 476**] known to cause
   prolonged high fevers and course is known to be more severe in HIV
   positive patients however fevers are of impressive duration and
   severity.  warrants probe for alternative sources of which he has many
    - ID consulted, appreciate their input. CT sinus/torso without
   evidence of source of infection.  Though patient does have pleural
   effusion so need to consider thoracentesis.  [**Month (only) 51**] need IP to do [**Female First Name (un) 217**]
   - continue levaquin for PNA.  on vanco/cefipime for broad spectrum
   coverage.  Pan culture
   -  found to have DVT in R popliteal/superficial femoral.  s/p IVC
   filter
   - may need to consider CT head to look for central source; also to eval
   for herniation.  [**Month (only) 51**] need for LP for meningitis but first would need CT
   head.  Will hold off today while adjust vent settings.  [**Month (only) 51**] be
   something to do this PM or tomorrow if patient tolerates AC and ABG is
   good
   - central line re-sited.  Culture of tip pending.  Possible source for
   fever.  [**Month (only) 51**] also consider TEE to eval for endocarditis though TTE
   without evidence of valvular disease and blood cultures negative
   - sent fungal cultures; not covering for fungal though unlikely.
   - ATC tylenol
   - cooling blankets PRN
   #. Acute Kidney Injury- urine sediment with casts c/w ATN.  Cr
   improving. No hyperkalemia, still making urine, no indication for
   dialysis at present.
   - cont to monitor.  Esp post CT scan
   - will renally dose medications.
   #. Hypernatremia-
   -  Free H2O deficit improving; cont free H2O flushes 350 cc/4H.  may
   need to decrease if sodium continues to decline
   #Elevated pancreatic enzymes- improving now.
   - no inciting factor noted at this time. CT without evidence of
   pancreatitis.  Likely medication induced; or possibly [**2-20**] hypotension
   -Continue tube feedsand titrate up to goal per nutrition
